Another commonly cited reason for residential appreciation is the impact of baby boomers reaching their peak earning years, and subsequently' investing' in residential real estate. The holes in this theory are countless, so I'll point out just the most obvious few.
 
 Why would anybody invest in new, expensive, single-family homes? There is no rental market for these homes because rental income would be a fraction of the amortizing mortgage payments. Rental homes are by definition lower-quality properties in older neighborhoods.
 
 Why would anybody invest in rental properties when rental vacancies and homeownership have both reached record highs? Most of the renters are now homeowners, so investing in rental properties would not be wise at this time.
 
 I've seen the following 'fact' cited numerous times. "Baby boomers are buying second (vacation) homes." Wow, I had no idea baby boomers wanted to spend their holidays in 4,000 square foot McMansions in the middle of ugly, urban sprawl. Whoever invented this theory should be embarrassed.
 
 Baby boomers should be collectively outraged because the bubble supporters are making the boomers look like fools.
 
 Or maybe there is something to this theory after all. Maybe boomers are speculating in residential real estate. What are the odds? Of course they are, just like all the other speculators, and they will get burned as badly.
